statement.p: You wish to test the following claim (\displaystyle{H}_{{a}}) at a significance level of \displaystyle\alpha={0.05}.

You obtain a sample of size \displaystyle{n}_{{1}}={42} with a mean of \displaystyle{M}_{{1}}={90.2} and a standard deviation of \displaystyle{S}{D}_{{1}}={20.1} from the first population. You obtain a sample of size \displaystyle{n}_{{2}}={108} with a mean of \displaystyle{M}_{{2}}={86.8} and a standard deviation of \displaystyle{S}{D}_{{2}}={13.6} from the second population.

What is the critical value for this test? For this calculation, use the conservative under-estimate for the degrees of freedom. This is the minimum of {n}_{1} minus 1 or {n}_{2} minus 1. (Report answer accurate to three decimal places.)
What is the test statistic for this sample? (Report answer accurate to three decimal places.)
This test statistic leads to a decision to...
As such, the final conclusion is that...

ol.li: There is sufficient evidence to warrant rejection of the claim that the first population mean is greater than the second population mean.
There is not sufficient evidence to warrant rejection of the claim that the first population mean is greater than the second population mean.
The sample data support the claim that the first population mean is greater than the second population mean.
There is not sufficient sample evidence to support the claim that the first population mean is greater than the second population mean.

ul.li: B: not in the critical region
C: fail to reject the null
D: There is not sufficient sample evidence to support the claim that the first population mean is greater than the second population mean.
